text: There you have it! 31 days of horror movies. Fare thee well October. Have fun & be safe tonight! Until next time! Happy Halloween! üéÉ
10/31) Halloween III: Season of the Witch. I resisted it for years due to the lack of Michael Myers but now I love this nihilistic 80s gem.
10/30) The Innkeepers. Filmmaker Ti West puts his unique and mercurial stamp on the haunted hotel genre.
10/29) The Conjuring 2. Director James Wan continues to excel at long slow sequences of supernatural suspense.
My buddy @aaronleetasjan1 has a terrific new record out on @newwestrecords called Silver Tears. Pick it up and give it a spin!
10/28) The Hills Have Eyes ('06). It is a well kept secret that this groundbreaking Wes Craven classic also got a surprisingly good remake.
10/27) The Other. This slow
column4: stylish and simple story about mysterious identical twin boys is a successor of sorts to The Bad Seed.

text: @jefplate Haven't watched it yet but I'm psyched to check it out! Dan is a mad talented dude.
10/26) Resident Evil. Video game adaptations are never quite perfect but I still have a little soft spot for this one.
My band @lakestheband fronted by @libberation is playing @cmoneverybodybk w/ @narctwain & @zachjonesmusic Sat
column4: 11/5! https://t.co/SAPGlEDY5m

text: 10/25) Frailty. Bill Paxton directs himself and a great ensemble in this trippy Hitchcockian throwback that will keep you guessing.
10/24) The Lost Boys. Joel Schumacher gives the vampire tale an edgy 1980s upgrade in this leather & chain wrapped amusement park ride.
@francie_berens Nope! Just random recommendations with 2 rules. I have to have seen the film and not have recommended it in previous years.
@markstepro Oh my word! I remember the cover of Another Brick in the Wall but forgot about Creed doing Cooper. Ah '98. Simpler times.
@aaronleetasjan1 I haven't caught it yet but really want to! I like all of the people who made it. Perhaps tonight I shall rent it!
@DannyTRS I'm breaking out some deep cuts this year!
10/23) The Faculty. A charming creature feature sleeper from Kevin Williamson and Robert Rodriguez. The Breakfast Club with aliens.
10/22) Trollhunter. A surprisingly refreshing and impressive Norwegian found footage entry. Silly yet grounded and a whole lot of fun.
10/21) Christine. Carpenter does King and tells the tale of an outcast teenager who buys an old car with mysterious and sinister powers.
10/20) Killer Klowns From Outer Space. An insanely strange and  surreal experience. It oozes earnestness and camp in (mostly) equal measure.
10/19) Mimic. A genetically engineered breed of insect created to kill disease carrying roaches wreaks havoc in NYC. Vintage del Toro.
10/18) Orphan. A grieving husband and wife adopt an innocent young girl (or so they think!) to heal and their world is turned upside down.
Beware sweet old ladies in bars who love theater & don't tell them you're an actor cuz they might spend 5 mins EVISCERATING your last play.
10/17) Teeth. Just watch this one. There is nothing quite like it.
10/16) The Invitation. An utterly superb study in tension and expectation with a stellar cast. Brilliantly done. Watch it on Netflix now.
@gideonyago You are too kind! I think most people view my movie recommendations as more of a national annoyance.
10/15) The Exorcism of Emily Rose. A breakout role for Jennifer Carpenter as a young woman who may or may not be possessed by a demon.
10/14) A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors. My personal favorite Freddy Krueger sequel.
Playing @RockwoodNYC tonight at 10 pm with my band. Times are tough but at least there are electric guitars
column4: records and songs. Come on out!

text: 10/13) House of 1
column4: 000 Corpses. After years of worshipping the genre
column5: Rob Zombie takes his own stab with this ode to midnight movies of yore.

text: 10/12) Sinister. A true crime author with writer's block moves his family into a murder house and learns much more than he bargained for.
10/11) The Fly (86). Another inventive remake
column4: this time from pro mind-bender David Cronenberg. Monster movie meets Kafka...and Goldblum.

text: 10/10) Cape Fear (91). Scorcese boldly remakes a classic 1962 thriller & coaxes a genius performance from De Niro as a vengeful ex-con.
10/9) Evil Dead 2. One of the more delightfully insane horror movie sequels ever made.
10/8) Land of the Dead. After a 20 year absence
column4: George A. Romero returns home to the tried and true zombie genre he created.

text: Last time I spoke to anyone in a locker room it was John Slattery. I was like "I'm doing Long Day's" he was like "I'm doing The Front Page."
10/7) They Live. The masterful John Carpenter serves up scary social satire
column4: campy commentary & one of the most epic fight scenes ever.

text: 10/6) The Last House on the Left ('09). I rarely get down with remakes of classics but a killer cast and a refusal to dilute make this one.
10/5) The Relic. The Douglas Preston/Lincoln Child bestseller gets a mostly loyal big screen treatment in this museum set creature feature.
10/4) The Legend of Hell House. The brilliant Richard Matheson adapts his bold and spine tingling haunted house novel for the big screen.
10/3) It. I still adore this Stephen King miniseries. Both eras of the Losers Club are wonderfully cast & Tim Curry slays as Pennywise.

Thanks everybody for putting up with yet another October of horror movie recommendations. Happy Halloween! Have fun. Be safe. Til next year!
10/31) Halloween H20. Steve Miner brings back Jaime Lee Curtis and offers the most loyal take on Michael Myers since the Carpenter days.
And the final horror movie recommendation for the month of October is...............
10/30) The Craft. High school cliques can be evil. In this movie they are actual witches. I had the album & a crush on Fairuza Balk in '96.
10/29) Shocker. The late great Wes Craven creates yet another crazed and ruthless serial killer who operates beyond the material world.
10/28) Seven. To be honest I wouldn't put this Fincher knockout in the horror section but it does get under the skin in ways few others can.
Thrilled to announce I'll be opening for the fantastic @anaismitchell Fri/Nov 6 at Marblehead
column4: MA's @MeTheeCoffee! https://t.co/J3Dd2Mtcu8

text: 10/27) Drag Me to Hell. Sam Raimi delighted superfans (myself included) by returning to his horror roots in this fun tale of a spooky curse.
10/26) Slither. The great James Gunn leads a killer cast to fun
column4: campy
column5: gory sci-if/horror/comedy glory in this fresh creature feature.

text: 10/25) Wolf Creek. Aussie-indie features a charming and maniacal villain for the ages
column4: makes you think twice about camping in the outback.

text: 10/24) Black Christmas. This POV heavy chiller was made 4 years before Halloween and is considered to be one of the first slasher films.
10/23) Cujo. Simple premise of a mother and son trapped in a stalled car being circled by a rabid dog elevated by great editing.
10/22) Dead Silence. James Wan starts to play with the freaky witch & creepy doll imagery he'll later perfect in Insidious & The Conjuring.
So delightful to see the amazing Marylouise Burke reunited with @lindsayabaire in his beautiful new play Ripcord at @MTC_NYC last night!
10/21) From Dusk Till Dawn. The pairing of Quentin Tarantino & Robert Rodriguez makes for a fun
column4: twisted

text: 10/20) Slumber Party Massacre. Written as a sexism revealing slasher flick satire but then directed in earnest. The results are fascinating.
10/19) Kill List. I still don't really know what happened in this mysterious bloody British head trip about hit men but it freaked me out.

text: 10/17) Oculus. The great Mike Flanagan serves up a wildly imaginative and sure handed tale about a haunted mirror. At once simple and epic.
10/16) High Tension. It may be a rip off of Intensity by Dean Koontz & the plot twist may be thin but the 1st 30 mins are brutal & scarring.

10/8) Day of the Dead. Probably the darkest of Romero's Dead films but with striking visuals & themes to be copied by future zombie movies.
10/7) Child's Play. Before Annabelle there was the foul mouthed knife wielding possessed doll Chucky voiced with evil glee by Brad Dourif.
10/6) Lady in White. Dunno how it holds up but this ghost story murder mystery terrified me as a kid. Len Cariou+Lukas Haas+Alex Rocco=üëçüèª.
10/5) The Amityville Horror. Despite post release debunking of the "true" source material
column4: this remains an influential haunted house entry.

text: @DannyTRS It's that time of year again! It's definitely either the most fun or the most annoying thing I do on Twitter.
10/4) New Nightmare. The late great Wes Craven returned to reinvent the stagnant Freddy franchise he created in this meta post modern gem.
10/3) The Hitcher. C. Thomas Howell picks up a creepy hitchhiking Rutger Hauer on a long stretch of desert highway. What could go wrong?!
10/2) Session 9. An asbestos crew is hired to clean an abandoned mental asylum but end up uncovering even darker secrets in this slow burn.
10/1) The Babadook. A nightmarish yet beautiful take on the power of grief. This Aussie indie features the creepiest children's book ever.

column4: 31 scary movies. Happy Halloween everyone. Have fun out there

text: 10/31. Halloween. One of my horror heroes John Carpenter broke the mold when he basically invented the modern slasher flick as we know it.
10/30. The Exorcist. 1 of my fav films ever made. Friedken's take on Blatty's mortifying novel is nothing short of pure cinematic genius.
10/29. The Haunting. The original. The quintessential "hey let's go spend the night in this haunted house" movie. Also...Russ Tamblyn!
10/28. Alien. The trailer alone for Ridley Scott's deep space nightmare masterpiece gives me chills every time. A perfect film all over.
10/27. The Mist. Frank Darabont's take on Stephen King's apocalyptic tale of trapped supermarket patrons. 1 of the best King films IMHO.
About to do some songs at PostCrypt coffee house @ Columbia University. All songs will be to the tune of Tales From the Crypt theme song.
If you'd told me that one day Lara Croft would invite me to a party and I'd decline I would've laughed in your face. Ha! But it's true.
10/26. The Sixth Sense. A surprise home run of by then unknown M. Night Shyamalan. Great concept
column4: scares

text: 10/25. The Last House on the Left. Lose the distracting music & odd comic relief cop duo & voila; Wes Craven's revolutionary indie horror.
10/24. Shaun of the Dead. Saw it's original release in theaters in London. Jumped and laughed 'til I cried. Spot on zombie satire/homage.
10/23. Let the Right One In. An entirely original spin on vampires makes this less of a horror film and more of a coming of age love tale.
10/22. The Omen. It's all for you Damien!
I'll be stopping by The Bedford in Williamsburg tonight to do a tune or two at Shayni Rae's Truckstop. Gunna see my pal @ALTisyourenemy !
We must all deeply thank @PunkRockMarthas for renovating the Elliott Smith Figure 8 wall in LA to a most well deserved memorial condition.
@PunkRockMarthas Thank you so much for renovating the memorial wall. I drive by it all the time & it broke my heart how far it fell. Bravo!
10/21. Wait Until Dark. No ghosts/goblins just a trend setting "bad guy" performance by Alan Arkin as he terrorizes a blind Audrey Hepburn.
@ScottPorter You can come to the child naming ceremony! Wait does that exist? Is that a thing?
10/20. Rosemary's Baby. All of them witches! This one is so well done and gets right under your skin. Even Charles Grodin is creepy!
How much do you think my kid is gonna love me when I name them Dillon Panther Gallagher 'cause I think probably a lot.
10/19. The Shining. Sure Kubrick was less than faithful to King's brilliant novel but with results so stunning it's a forgivable offense.
The trailer for Flight proves it is baller and doesn't give a f by featuring both Feelin' Alright AND Gimme Shelter.
10/18. Stir of Echoes. David Koepp directs adaptation of Richard Matheson's book. Widely overlooked due to release close to The Sixth Sense.
I have to shave my beard for work. There goes being The Dude for Halloween.
10/17. The Others. Saw is in the theater several times. I was young at the time but still...yikes.
Playing a surprise last minute show TONIGHT! for CMJ fest NYC at Rockwood Music Hall Stage 2. 9:30 pm. No cover.
10/16. The Changeling. Still scary. Has to be one of the best haunted house movies ever. Not to be confused with Clint's film Changeling.
@francesca_homes Fear not! I've given away nothing that can't be found in the trailers/comics.
10/15. Psycho. Needs no explanation really.
10/14. Insidious. Despite a slightly shakey finale I found this to be one of the creepier new original scary movies of the last few years.

10/10. The Texas Chainsaw Massacre. You simply can't mess with this totally original piece of pulp grindhouse horrorshow.
10/9. The Thing. One of John Carpenter's finest and easily one of the greatest remakes of all time in any genre. Great creature effects.
10/8. Eden Lake. Relentless British horror. Fassbender vs. hooligans. 1 of the most upsetting endings since Night of the Living Dead.

10/2. Jacob's Ladder. Adrian Lyne takes a break from sexual thrillers & F's with your head. Unsettling as heck Home run perf by Tim Robbins.
10/1. The Evil Dead. Sam Raimi's bloody arrival as a premiere master of cult camp horror comedy & Bruce Campbell as hero Ash. Groovy.

I am epically jealous of my friends who saw Arcade Fire@MSG last night. I'll have to settle for restreamed highlights of Gilliam's webcast.
Jay-Z is going to publish his memoir. That'll be a serious tell all. I'm glad he didn't pull a Bieber and release it when he was a teenager.
Everyone must read this book. It should be taught in schools. http://twitpic.com/2bzccz
My 1st show at Rockwood Music Hall's stage 2 is this Sunday night at 8. 21+ No cover. It's bigger than stage 1. Let's pack 'em in!
Since a few have asked
column4: I am all better and back in AI as of last night and therefore have no excuse for watching all of the Elm Streets.

text: My mother is totally "cell phone in the air at a concert" dialing me from the Green Day show in Camden!
One step closer to finishing the Elm Street series. Watched part 5: The Dream Child. I now can't decide which sequel makes less sense.
And you will not once hear me talk ill or slanderously about any of my brilliant castmates.
And I would never suggest that the quality of our show would suffer merely because of my absence. It is worlds bigger than any one person.
American Idiot has the most talented group of swings/understudies I have ever seen in my life and they never ever fail to deliver.
My apology was being offered from a performer who purely hates to not be onstage at his job. No disrespect meant to the amazing AI cast.
I got shut down and bed ridden by sickness this weekend. My true apologies to all seeing American Idiot. It is killing me to not be there.
Confession: I also own The Stand DVD. I've always had a soft spot for the King miniseries.
Finally finished Stephen King's The Stand. 1
column4: 159 pages. Longest book I've read. It is amazing. So unapologatically epic. Bold and brave.

text: The panel I did for the American Theater Wing last month is now available to stream and download. http://tinyurl.com/35oqz42
My show at Rockwood Stage 2 Sunday August 8th is at 8 PM not 8:30. Hope to see you all there!
I'm playing 3 shows on 3 Sundays in the next 3 months at Rockwood Music Hall stage 2! August 8 @ 8:30
That was some storm! Huge thunderclap audible in the theater during Last Night on Earth. Very moody indeed!
Van Hughes and I just saw Keanu Reeves hail a cab on 49th street. He's sporting a pretty groovy beard currently. Keanu that is. Not Van.
@hitRECordJoe is definitely the most bad ass thing on screen in Inception. Apparently no stunt double for the hallway fight scene!
All of the new cast members in American Idiot are fearlessly killing it on the St. James stage!
Also totally worth checking Inception out in IMAX. Visually and aurally thrilling.
LOVED Inception. Wildly inventive filmmaking. Great cast. I was transfixed. Definitely gonna need a repeated viewing. Sufficiently mindblown
Inception IMAX! Here we go. So psyched but if the people around me keep up their current level of talking there will be hell to pay.
Thank you to Ars Nova for having me and to everyone who came out to the show last night. It meant a great deal to me.
I had an amazing cab driver tonight. He gave me a history lesson about a building almost every 5 blocks or so on the way to Brooklyn.
Forgive me. Scottsboro Boys...with two t's.
And you must all go see him star in the Scotsboro Boys on Broadway this fall!
Joshua Henry's last performance in American Idiot was tonight. He is a touched and talented soul and performer and he will be so missed.
My benefit show at Ars Nova is sold out tomorrow! Thanks to all for supporting the theater and independent arts. Looking forward to it!
Only a couple of tickets left for my show at Ars Nova tomorrow night. Get 'em while they last!
Holy cow I need to see Inception. 1 of my fav modern filmmakers & Joe G Levitt and Cillian Murphy are 2 of the best new gen superfilmstars.
Keep this on your radar. It is a MUST SEE production. Co-conceived and directed by the brilliant Steven Hoggett. http://tinyurl.com/2vx5tzd
I just napped it out like a champ. I want to be well rested for the 100th performance of American Idiot on Broadway tonight!
That was so much fun! What a crowd! Thanks for getting up so early to come be with us this morning. You're all beautiful and you spoiled us.
Thanks all for reminding me about the Borders near MSG. It's my closest option unless I need a play then it's Drama Book Shop (which rocks).
@jaredgeller Perhaps "supposed epicenter" would have been a more apt reference. Yeah that's more like it!
Ahhh Times Square. The epicenter of the East Coast yet not a single bookstore to be found.
And Brian Helgeland cuts his teeth writing scripts for horror franchise films. Death scenes get weirder and more unneccessarily creative.
Part 4. Patricia Arquette replaced by Tuesday Knight who also sings credits song. Renny Harlin helms. Plot has holes. Freddy makes puns.
Remember when I said I was gonna watch all the NightmaresOnElmStreet and then stopped? Just started up again.

column4: a camera

text: I'm going to be on ABC News Now in a half an hour at 1:00 PM. Tune in if you so desire!
Thanks kindly to all for my birthday wishes last week. A Dairy Queen commercial informed me that I'm one year older than the blizzard.
The finale of Treme left me speechless. Beautifully articulated and honestly captured. An important American TV series. Bring on season 2!
Happy Fathers Day Pops!
A film I'm in called Jonah Hex hits theaters Friday. If you're planning on seeing it
column4: why not check it out opening weekend! Eh?!

text: And having said that
column4: theater award season is over! May we all continue to run our shows with commitment and passion 8 times a week.

text: Big ole congrats to Kevin Adams & Christine Jones. Equally beautiful as artists and humans. Kudos to Kevin for the "extra honest" speech.
It's fuck time!
Soundcheck and dress rehearsal was pretty exciting today. This will be fun. Go Kevin Adams! Go Christine Jones!
We just did 15 shows back to back over a two week period with no day off. Not quite sure how we managed that but we did. Tomorrow
column4: Tonys!

text: No day off! No mercy! Come see American Idiot tonight. We're one of the few B'way shows with a Monday night performance this week.
My parents used to take me and my sister to Appel Farm Music Festival every summer. So wish I could've been there today to see The Avetts!
Happy Birthday Levon!
Didn't mean to be ill spirited or overly serious about award season by using the word justice. Just real excited for my friend. That's all.
Thanks to all who voted for me in the Broadway.com audience awards. I very much appreciate it.
HELL YES! MICHAEL MAYER! JUSTICE! WINNER! CONGRATS!

text: So apparently it's November in NYC. Don't like it. But I'm with my mom and my sis on mothers day and that makes me feel warmer than ever!
